name: Akari
comment info:
1. What do you notice? 
    I notice that when the pandemic happened in 2020, a lot of things in the U.S. changed. Many people died, a lot lost their jobs, and people started spending more money on food from stores instead of eating at restaurants. I also see that people didn’t hang out as much, and even after the pandemic, things never really went back to normal. 
    2. What do you wonder?
    I wonder how long these changes will last and if people’s habits will ever completely go back to normal. For example, will people keep working from home, shopping online more, and hanging out less? I also wonder how these long-term lifestyle changes will affect young people like me in the future. 
    3. How does this relate to you and your community?
    This relates to my community because the pandemic also changed the way people around me live and work. Many people in Japan started wearing masks and spending less time outside or meeting friends. Schools and workplaces moved to online systems, and habits like wearing masks all the time still remain. 
    4. Create a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
    “How Covid Ruined Americans’ Everyday Life and It Still Hasn’t Gone Back.”

name: Carter
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
    
    Almost all the graphs spiked during the 2020 Covid pandemic, except for third through eighth grade U.S levels, eating at restaurants, and time socializing with others. Most increases were a straight jump up, meaning a sharp exponential graph.
    
    
    2. What do you wonder?
    
    I wonder what other searches and items that were popular? Were there more recipes searched for, or toilet paper sales increased?
    
    3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
    
    This has an impact on me and my community because it shows me the struggles that others were going through such as unemployment, skills they had to learn like cutting other people’s hair, and it shows me to have empathy for those that now may be struggling with school because of the major world shift.
    
    4. What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
    
    The rise and fall of our lives during Covid.

name: Annelore
comment info:
1. I notice that in each of the graphs, there is a sudden increase or decrease during the time period of COVID-19. For example, the Unemployment claims graph went from fewer than half a million claims before March 2020 to over 6 million unemployment claims around March 
    2. I wonder at what point each graph starts to even out and go back to its track before COVID. Many of the graphs seem to look similar to before the pandemic, and I wonder if it was because of the pandemic ending or the improvement of the U.S..
    3. This has made an impact on me and my community because we have seen a shift between before the pandemic, during, and after. During the pandemic, the employment rates were high, our test scores were going down, we spent less time socializing, and more. Now that COVID is not as big of a problem anymore, everything is switching back to relatively how it was before the pandemic.     4. "A ripple in time"

name: Aadit
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
    
    The graph shows a dramatic spike in web searches for “How to cut your own hair” in March 2020, aligning with the start of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdowns. Prior to this point, search interest remained consistently low. After peaking, the trend declined sharply but stayed somewhat elevated compared to pre-pandemic levels, suggesting a lasting, though reduced, interest in DIY grooming.
    
    2. What do you wonder?
    
    I wonder how long people continued cutting their own hair after salons reopened, and whether some individuals permanently changed their habits as a result. It also raises curiosity about whether similar search spikes occurred for other self-care routines during the pandemic, and how that reflects changes in consumer behavior and independence.
    
    3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
    
    This graph is a clear reflection of how communities quickly adapted to sudden disruptions during the COVID-19 pandemic. With salons closed, people turned to the internet to find ways to manage basic grooming needs themselves. In my community, this led to a surge in shared tips, YouTube tutorials, and even virtual haircutting lessons—fostering both resourcefulness and a temporary shift away from professional services.
    
    4. What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
    
    "Pandemic Hair Panic: How Lockdowns Sparked a DIY Haircut Surge"

name: Evan
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
    Almost every measure like deaths, unemployment, grocery spending, and online shopping jumped or dropped sharply in March 2020. Some stayed above pre-pandemic levels. Others (like restaurants and unemployment) bounced back but not always fully.
    2. What do you wonder?
    Will extra deaths settle back to normal or point to longer-term health effects? Is the rise in working moms due to remote work, childcare changes, or financial need? And will shifts in shopping, car prices, and school scores continue or reverse?

    Higher groceries are putting pressure on family budgets, while schools cope with learning loss. More moms working means more income but also challenges with childcare access. Ongoing health concerns and new shopping habits are reshaping local services and business plans.
    4. What’s going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
    Pandemic Shockwaves: Sudden Spikes, New Norms

name: Anastasiia
comment info:
Covid social(media?)lizing 
    
    
    The graph clearly shows a significant jump in socializing in 2021, likely driven by the easing of pandemic restrictions and a strong desire for reconnection after prolonged isolation. However, this surge was followed by a decrease in 2022. This decline could be attributed to lingering COVID-19 concerns, the emergence of new variants, or the persistence of social habits formed during the pandemic.
    
    My main question revolves around the definition of "socializing" used in the graph. The term is broad, encompassing everything from in-person interactions at school or social events to online communication via social media. The lack of specificity makes it difficult to fully understand the data. Clarification on the types of socializing included would greatly improve the graph's interpretability
    
    Like many communities, we've seen a growing reliance on social media for communication, sometimes at the expense of in-person interactions. The graph, even without specifying the type of socializing, highlights the pandemic's impact on our social lives and the importance of finding a healthy balance between online and offline connections. It makes me consider how I can engage meaningful relationships in a world increasingly mediated by technology

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Anastasiia I think it's really interesting how you noticed that the surge in socializing in 2021 was followed by a decrease in 2022 and I think the possible reasons that you provided would definitely make sense.

name: Ciara AOSE
comment info:
The first thing I noticed about this graph was that some trends were already underway before the pandemic. Deaths, online shopping, women in the workforce, “how to cut your own hair” searches, and spending on groceries were all on the rise. Also, education scores and time socializing with others were both declining. These trends suggest that the pandemic only exacerbated existing issues in the country. I also noticed that many changes during the pandemic have not returned to their pre-pandemic levels. name: Lila
comment info:
Headline: The pandemic has passed, but effects still linger
    
    Overall, although the effects of the pandemic were greatest during 2020-2021, Americans still experience the impacts of the pandemic today. As a student in high school, I've noticed the declining trend in the time socializing with others as a major impact from the pandemic. Since returning from online school, students are increasingly less likely to interact with one another, especially as many students decide to turn to their phones in their free time as opposed to starting a conversation with others they're physically sitting around. Additionally, although the US scores on reading and math exams are only for 3rd-8th graders, my current high school teachers have mentioned the trend is also present in high school, especially evident in the grading of nationwide exams like AP exams that have begun making their rubrics slightly easier for students. The time online definitely set students back, and the education system is having to create new standards for students to adjust to their learning setbacks. I do wonder about the used car prices graph because there was an extremely steep incline all the way up to February 2022. Although prices have begun decreasing in recent years, I'm still confused as to why the prices shot up this much for used cars.

name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
Headline: “Life After Lockdown: How Our Community Evolved—and What’s Next”
    
    The graphs compare key indicators before, during, and after the pandemic and reveal significant shifts across economic, social, and educational dimensions: death rates fluctuated sharply; unemployment claims spiked at the onset before settling at low levels; restaurant spending fell while grocery expenditures rose, only for dining out to later surpass grocery bills; used‑car prices climbed to a peak in February 2022; women’s labor‑force participation dipped and then recovered by 2022; online shopping remained elevated as a continuing trend; social interactions declined markedly compared to pre‑2020; student test scores in grades 3–8 fell from 2019 baselines—particularly in math—while reading proved more resilient; and searches for “how to cut your own hair” surged in 2022 before leveling off. These patterns underscore the pandemic’s broad and lasting impact on daily life.I wonder if student performance will bounce back to where it was before the pandemic, especially in math, and what steps will help them catch up. This relates to my community because we all went through these changes. Personally, my family still buys more groceries than we eat out at restaurants out of habit of the pandemic.

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
Observations - In the years leading up to March 2020 (2015-19), the total US deaths per week were numbering below 60,000, with the spike in 2018 being the sole exception. Unemployment claims were also relatively low, but they skyrocketed in March 2020 at 6 million claims per week. The share of women in the workforce decreased, but gradually increased beyond its pre pandemic numbers. Online shopping saw a sharp increase after March 2020, and so did the price of used cars. People began socializing a lot less, (possibly as a byproduct of social distancing, as also seen with the increased web searches of “How to Cut Your Own Hair”) and US Scores 3rd grade thru 8th declined. 
    
    Questions - Beyond the initial shock, how has the pandemic changed daily life in the U.S? What long-term effects are we seeing (or will see) in education, the economy, and social behaviors? And most importantly, how do we measure recovery - by numbers or by well-being?
    
    Relation to Community - These trends hit close to home in NJ. Most, if not all communities have faced an unemployment crisis and education gaps. These effects can still be felt up to this day. 
    
    Headline - Ctrl + Alt + COVID: Unpacking the Metrics Behind America’s Pause!

name: Kian Beeck
comment info:
When looking at these graphs, it’s clear how much the COVID-19 pandemic affected our daily lives and the lives of others. From socializing to education to employment, the pandemic had an immediate and sweeping effect. US students in grades 3–8 saw test scores plummet in both math and reading, probably because of so many people switching to online learning.
    
    Additionally, millions more people almost immediately lost their jobs and claimed unemployment, and people started eating out much less often. I wonder what kind of effect that had on the American economy with so much less money circulating suddenly. I also wonder if the online shopping market would have risen so sharply if there had not been a pandemic, as our shopping has become increasingly digital even without the pandemic, and it looks like the trend was going upwards anyway. Finally, I wonder why some of the spikes in the graphs happen a decent time after COVID-19 hit and why the effects were delayed in some areas.
    
    This closely relates to me and my country because I had to attend school online in 2020 and personally experienced the global wave of social isolation the pandemic caused. Looking back on it, it’s crazy to see the impact on all aspects of life, and it truly shows how much our lives were reshaped.
    
    I would call these graphs “How Covid-19 reshaped our lives overnight.”

replies.name: A

Good morning, @Drew Rossom --

Also, the reading and math decreases will permanently harm the future because that generation of children will be slightly less proficient in the workforce.”

When many diverse groups are put together, the resulting statistics “iron out” (reduce) the variations that exists from group to group.  Example:  Age of your entire school (that includes your stat class) versus the age of your stats class.

name: Lavon
comment info:
1) What do you notice?
    A clear theme emerges across these graphs: although the pandemic occurred five years ago, its impact continues to linger. Academic performance has yet to fully recover, vehicle prices remain elevated, and most significantly, our levels of social interaction are still noticeably lower than before. There is no clear indication of when, or if, these trends will return to pre-pandemic norms.
    2) What do you wonder?
    What will society look like in twenty or thirty years? Will the decline in standardized testing outcomes lead to shortages in certain professions? Could this hinder technological and scientific progress? I also wonder are the unseen, lasting effects on our ability to connect with one another with us being disconnected for so long?
    3) How does this relate to you and your community?
    Perhaps the most vital part of our lives is human connection. One might assume that, once the world reopened, our social behaviors would bounce back to normal. Yet the data and my personal experience tells a different story. Sometimes, classrooms seem quieter, and students interact and participate less than they did before. It’s unnerving to think that the pandemic may have permanently reshaped how we interact with each other.
    4) What’s going on in this graph?
    A Silent Aftermath: How COVID-19 Changed the Way We Learn, Spend, and Connect
